questions.Question: Which of the following writers has called Akbar's Din-i-Ilahi as a monument of his folly, not of wisdom?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vincent Arthur Smith was a British Indologist and art historian, who stated that Akbar's Din-i-Ilahi was a monument of his folly, not of wisdom”.

questions.Question: Akbar's concept of Sulh-i-kul (or Qul) means
questions.solution: Solution:		Sulh-i kul is an Arabic term literally meaning “peace with all,” “universal peace,” or “absolute peace,” drawn from a Sufi mystic principle. As applied by the third Mughal Emperor of India, Akbar (who reigned 1556-1605), it described a peaceful and harmonious relationship among different religions.

questions.Question: Which of the following buildings at Fatehpur Sikri is known as Ibadatkhana where Akbar used to hold religious discussions?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Diwan-i-Khas, or Hall of Private Audiences, in the Red Fort of Delhi built in 1571 was the place where the Mughal emperor Akbar received courtiers and state guests. It was also known as the Shah Mahal.

questions.Question: Hemu was captured and brought before Akbar by__________
questions.solution: Solution:		Hemu was captured and brought before Akbar by Shah Qulihan Mehran.

questions.Question: Baz Bahadur was a . . . . . . in the court of Akbar
questions.solution: Solution:		Baz Bahadur famous musician of Akbar’s time, was made Manashba of 2000 by Akbar, the ruler of Malva. Abul Fazl wrote about him – “he was the best person of his time in music and Hindi songs.”

questions.Question: Who had built the 'Amber Fort'?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Amber fort was built by Raja Man Singh in the 16th century and was completed by Sawai Jai Singh in the 18th Century.

questions.Question: In which of the following towns is "Moti Masjid" situated?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Moti Masjid (translation: Pearl Mosque) in Agra was built by Shah Jahan. During the rule of Shah Jahan the Mughal emperor, numerous architectural wonders were built, the most famous of them being the Taj Mahal.

questions.Question: Babur summoned the pupils of the famous architect Sinan from
questions.solution: Solution:		Babur found leisure to summon from Constantinople pupils of the famous Albanian architect, Sinan, who had designed many important buildings in the Ottoman Empire and set them to work on mosques and other architectural monuments commemorating his conquest of Hindustan.

questions.Question:
The dead body of Babur by his own choice lies
buried in
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal Emperor Babur died in 1530. He was first buried at Aaram Bagh, Agra. Later his remains were moved to Bagh-e-Babur (Babur Gardevs),Kabul.

questions.Question: Name the Rajput General who bravely fought the Battle of Khanwa before losing to Babur
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Khanwa was fought near the village of Khanwa, in Bharatpur District of Rajasthan, on March 16, 1527. It was fought between the invading forces of the first Mughal Emperor Babur and the Rajput forces led by Rana Sanga of Mewar, after the Battle of Panipat.

questions.Question: In which year (in A.D) did Babur invaded India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Babur defeated Ibrahim Lodi at the First Battle of Panipat in 1526 AD and founded the Mughal empire.

questions.Question: In the battle of Panipat, Babur faced the armies of
questions.solution: Solution:		 Babur defeated Ibrahim Lodi in the First Battle of Panipat (AD 1526). This marked the end of the Delhi Sultanate and the beginning of the Mughal Empire. This was one of the earliest battles involving gunpowderfirearms and field artillery.

questions.Question: Which of the following Mughal King reign during the large scale famine in Gujarat and Deccan?
questions.solution: Solution:		On the one hand we hear of several famines which caused untold sufferings and on the other hand we hear the Golden Age of Shah Jahan.

questions.Question: The reputed musician duo, Tansen and Baiju Bawra, flourished during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		Baiju Bawra (Baijnath Mishra) he was the drupadh singer of Medieval period. Miyan Tansen was the Mystical court singer ofMughal emperor Akbar.

questions.Question: During the Mughal rule the finance minister was known as
questions.solution: Solution:		During the Mughal rule, the status of Diwan in the province was equal to the status of a modern day finance minister.His main responsibilities were collection of taxes on behalf of the emperor.

questions.Question: Which of the following is wrongly matched?
questions.solution: Solution:		Dantidurga (735–756 CE), also known as Dantivarman or Dantidurga II was the founder of the Rashtrakuta Empire of Manyakheta.

questions.Question: Battle for Delhi was fought in the year __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Delhi also known as the battle of Tughlaqabad was fought between Hemu (the General of Adil Shah Suri) and the Mughal forces led by Tardi Beg Khan in the year 1556. Hemu won the battle and over took Delhi.

questions.Question: The Battle of Haldighati was fought between
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Haldighati was a battle fought on 18 June 1576 between cavalry and archers supporting the Rana of Mewar, Maharana Pratap, and the Mughal emperor Akbar's forces, led by Man Singh I of Amber.

questions.Question: Who among the following had shifted the capital of the Mughal empire from Agra to Delhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Mughal emperor to crown Agra as capital of mughal empire, was Akbar in the year 1526. The capital of mughal empire was changed from Agra to Delhi by Shah Jahan in the year 1638.

questions.Question: In whose reign did the Mughal painting reach its zenith?
questions.solution: Solution:		In Jahangir's reign did the Mughal painting reach its zenith.

questions.Question: Which of the following was defended by Chand Bibi against the Mughals?
questions.solution: Solution:		Chand Bibi is best known for defending Ahmednagar against the Mughal forces of Emperor Akbar in 1595.

questions.Question: A hearty welcome was extended to the English captain Hawkins by the Mughal Emperor
questions.solution: Solution:		A hearty welcome was extended to the English captain Hawkins by the Mughal Emperor Jahangir, and on this the Portuguese got angry.

questions.Question: Who said the given statement - "I came alone and I am going alone. I have not done well to the country and the people, and of the future there is no hope"
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurangzeb said the given statement - "I came alone and I am going alone. I have not done well to the country and the people, and of the future there is no hope".

questions.Question: Name the Indian king who warmly received the Portuguese traveller Vasco da Gama when he landed at Calicut
questions.solution: Solution:		The king of Calicut, Zamorin welcomed Vasco-da-gama when he landed at calicut in 1498.

questions.Question: Who among the following attacked the Somnath temple?
questions.solution: Solution:		The prominent Turkic ruler Mahmud of Ghazni raided Gujarat, plundering the Somnath temple and breaking its jyotirlinga despite pleas by Brahmins not to break it. He took away a booty of 20 million dinars.

questions.Question: Name the language that was designated as the 'Camp Language' during the Medieval Period
questions.solution: Solution:		Urdu was designated the camp language of Medieval India. The word Urdu is a Turkish word that means military camp 'a Lashkar'. Urdu language was developed due to contact of Hindu, Turkish and Afghan soldiers.

questions.Question: Who among the following Mughal Emperors was half Rajput?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jahangir was half-Rajput and quarter-Persian, and Shah Jahan was three-quarters Rajput.

questions.Question: Who is the only women historian to have written a historical account of Mughal Period?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gulbadan Begum (1523-1603) was a Perso-Turkic Princess, the daughter of Emperor Babur. She is most known as the author of Humayun Nama, the account of the life of her brother, Humayun.

questions.Question: Under the Mughals, in urban area the judicial powers were exercised by
questions.solution: Solution:		Most of king's powers in urban areas were exercised by the kotwal, a secular functionary of the police, responsible under the Mughals for the peace of cities and towns.

questions.Question: Chand Bibi was the ruler of
questions.solution: Solution:		Chand Bibi (1550–1599 CE), was an Indian Muslim regent and warrior. She acted as the Regent of Bijapur (1580–90) and Regent of Ahmednagar (in current day Maharashtra) (1596–99). Chand Bibi is best known for defending Ahmednagar against the Mughal forces of Emperor Akbar in 1595.

questions.Question: Which Mughal emperor is credited with having composed secular Hindi songs?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal emperor Jahangir is credited with having composed secular Hindi songs.

questions.Question: Who got construced 'Grand Trunk Road'?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Grand Trunk Road, built by Sher Shah Suri, a ruler of the Indian sub continent in the 16th century AD, starts in Kabul, Afghanistan. The road continues to Pakistan near Peshawar through the famous Khyber Pass.

questions.Question: The East India Company was founded in India during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1612, James I instructed Sir Thomas Roe to visit the Mughal Emperor Nur-ud-din Salim Jahangir (r. 1605–1627) to arrange for a commercial treaty that would give the company exclusive rights to reside and establish factories in Surat and other areas.

questions.Question: The Mughal Emperor who caused the murder of Guru Arjan was
questions.solution: Solution:		Guru Arjan was arrested under the orders of the Mughal Emperor Jahangir and asked to convert to Islam. He refused, was tortured and executed in 1606 CE. Historical records and the Sikh tradition are unclear whether Guru Arjan was executed by drowning or died during torture.

questions.Question: Which Mughal Ruler's gave permission for collecting Chauth and Sardesh Mukhi on Maratha land to Peshwa Balaji Vishwanath?
questions.solution: Solution:		Farrukhsiyar gave permission for collecting Chauth and Sardesh Mukhi on Maratha land to Peshwa Balaji Vishwanath.

questions.Question: Two major crops introduced in India during the Mughal period were
questions.solution: Solution:		Two major crops introduced in India during the Mughal period were Tobacco and Maize.

questions.Question: When was the battle of Haldighati fought?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Haldighati was a battle fought on 18 June 1576 between cavalry and archers supporting the Rana of Mewar, Maharana Pratap; and the Mughal emperor Akbar's forces, led by Man Singh I of Amber.

questions.Question: Of the following, with whom Akbar did not come into contact?
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar did not come into contact with Buddhist.

questions.Question: In the year 1582, Akbar took the momentous step of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Din-i Ilahi (lit. "Religion of God") was a syncretic religion propounded by the Mughal emperor Akbar in 1582 CE, intending to merge some of the elements of the religions of his empire, and thereby reconcile the differences that divided his subjects.

questions.Question: Hemu, whom Akbar defeated In the Second Battle of Panipat (1556), was
questions.optionD: Prime Minister of Rana Udai Singh of Mewar
questions.solution: Solution:		The Second Battle of Panipat was fought on November 5, 1556, between the forces of Hemu, the Hindu general and Chief Minister of Adil Shah Suri, and the army of the Mughal emperor, Akbar.

questions.Question: Mansabdari System was founded by Akbar. The Mansabdars were
questions.solution: Solution:		Appointment to the ranks of mansabdars was made by the emperor, usually on the recommendation of military leaders, provincial governors, or court officials.

questions.Question: Akbar had constructed several forts, which did not include the one of
questions.solution: Solution:		The fort is called Red Fort or Lal QiIa because it is made of red sandstone. The history of forts indicates that it was built between the year 1639-1648 by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in old Delhi.

questions.Question: Where French established their first factory?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jean-Baptiste Colbert founded the French East India Company in 1664. The initial attempts of the company to found a successful colony on Madagascar got failed. In 1667, under Francis Caron, the company established first factory at Surat and second factory was established at Masulipattanam a year later.

questions.Question: What do you mean by Mughal Zagir?
questions.optionC: Giving officer a right to revenue
questions.solution: Solution:		Zagirdari system was the system of giving an official right to collect revenue from a particular area called 'Zagir'.

questions.Question: During the Mughal rule, the police duties in the districts were entrusted to the officials known as?
questions.solution: Solution:		During the Mughal rule, the police duties in the districts were entrusted to the officials known as Faujdar.

questions.Question: In the Mughal administration, military recruitment had been looked after by the
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Mughal administration, military recruitment had been looked after by the Bakhshi.

questions.Question: Which of the following Mughal emperors is credited with composition of Hindi songs?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal Emperor Jahangir had a keen interest in music. He also composed few hindi songs. Jahangir, the Mughal Emperor, is credited with the composition of many Hindi songs.

questions.Question:
I. Akbar's Gold Mohur bore the figures of Sita and Ram
II. Akbar's Gold Mohur bore the image of Prophet Mohammad
Which of the above statement (s) is/are correct related to the Akbar reign?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Ram Siya coin issued by Mughal Emperor Akbar in 1604-05. It has the image of Ram and Sita on one side with the word Ram and Siya written above in Devnagri script. Ram is shown holding a bow and arrow while Sita has lotus in both her hands.

questions.Question: To whom did Akbar gave the title Mian?
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar considered him as a Navaratnas (nine jewels), and gave him the title Mian, an honorific, meaning learned man. Tansen was a composer, musician and vocalist, to whom a large number of compositions have been attributed in northern regions of the Indian subcontinent.

questions.Question: The Mansabdari system introduced by Akbar was borrowed from the system prevalent in
questions.solution: Solution:		Mansabdar implies the generic term for the military-kind grading of all royal functionaries of the Mughal Empire. The Mansabdari system introduced by Akbar was borrowed from the system followed in Mongolia.

questions.Question: During Akbar's reign the Mahabharat was translated into Persian and is known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The "Razmnama"(war Tab) is the persian translation of the Mahabharta. Preface of this book was written by the Akbar's, court poet Abul Fazal.

questions.Question: Akbar founded the Din-i-Ilahi primarily to
questions.optionA: Establish a national religion which would be acceptable to the Muslims and the Hindus
questions.optionD: Put an end to differences between Hindus and Muslims
questions.solution: Solution:		One of Akbar's most unusual ideas regarding religion was Din-i-Ilahi (“Godism” in English), which was an eclectic mix of Hinduism, Islam, and Christianity.

questions.Question: Rana Pratap Singh of Mewar was defeated by the Mughal army in the battle of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Haldighati was a battle fought on 18 June 1576 between cavalry and archers supporting the Rana of Mewar, Maharana Pratap; and the Mughal emperor Akbar's forces, led by Man Singh I of Amber. After a fierce battle lasting more than three hours, Pratap found himself wounded and the day lost.

questions.Question: The Mughals imported fruits from
questions.solution: Solution:		Babur, the first Mughal emperor, was raised on a Central Asian diet that placed tremendous emphasis on the many fruits that passed through the region. In the markets of Samarkand one could purchase sweet apples, lush melons, and a bounty of other fruits from the region's orchards.

questions.Question: The Mughal emperor who had died owing to a sudden fall from the staircase was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mughal Emperor Humayun died after a sudden fall from the stairs of his library in his fort at Delhi in 1556 AD.

questions.Question: Permission to the British to establish their trading centre at Surat had been given by the Mughal emperor
questions.solution: Solution:		Sir Thomas Roe from company reached the court of the Mughal Emperor, Jahangir, as the emissary of King James I in 1615, and gained for the British the right to establish a factory at Surat.

questions.Question: Name the Pala ruler who was the first to plunge into the tripartite struggle
questions.solution: Solution:		Gopala of the Pala dynasty was the first to plunge into the tripartite struggle.

questions.Question: During whose reign did William Hawkins visit the Mughal court to secure a right. to trade in Mughal ports?
questions.solution: Solution:		During Jahangir's reign did William Hawkins visit the Mughal court to secure a right. to trade in Mughal ports.

questions.Question: Sawai Raja Jai Singh was the ruler of __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh (3 November 1688 – 21 September 1743) was the Hindu Rajput ruler of the kingdom of Amber (later called Jaipur). He was born at Amber, the capital of the Kachwahas. He became ruler of Amber at the age of 11 after his father Maharaja Bishan Singh died on 31 December 1699.

questions.Question: The Mughal architecture attained unrivalled magnificence during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal architecture reached its zenith during the reign of Shah Jahan, who constructed the Taj Mahal, the Jama Masjid, the Red Fort, and the Shalimar Gardens in Lahore.

questions.Question: Who got the Gita translated into Persian?
questions.solution: Solution:		So'aal o Jawaab bain-e-Laal Daas wa Dara Shikoh (also called Mukaalama-i Baba Laal Daas wa Dara Shikoh) Sirr-e-Akbar (The Great Secret, his translation of the Upanishads in Persian) Persian translations of the Yoga Vasishta and Bhagavad Gita.

questions.Question: The Mughal School of Painting was interested in portraying
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal painting remained confined to the Mughal court and did not reach the people.

questions.Question: During the last 25 years of his reign, Aurangzeb was mainly involved in long-drawn wars against
questions.solution: Solution:		During the last 25 years of his reign, Aurangzeb was mainly involved in long-drawn wars against Marathas.

questions.Question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding Aurangzeb?
I. He forbade the cultivation of Bhang
II. Forbade singing at court
III. A proficient player of Veena
IV. His tomb is at Tughlaqabad
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurangzeb forbaded the cultivation of Bhang. He forbaded singing at court and a proficient player of Veena.

questions.Question: Koh-i-noor diamond was presented to Aurangzeb by
questions.solution: Solution:		Mir Jumla (1591-1663) a nobleman in the service of the State of Golkonda in the Deccan plateau of Central India was the first owner of what was later known as the Kohinoor then the largest diamond in the world. Mir Jumla was a Persian born near Isfahan in Iran. He was the son of an oil merchant. Koh-i-noor diamond was presented to Aurangzeb by him.

questions.Question: Where did Aurangzeb died?
questions.solution: Solution:		 Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb died at the age of 88 in Ahmednagar in 1707. He died due to terminal illness.

questions.Question: Aurangzeb came to power after winning the war of succession and by defeating his three brothers
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurangzeb came to power after winning the war of succession and by defeating his three brothers Askari.

questions.Question: When was the second Anglo-Mysore War fought?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Second Anglo–Mysore War was a conflict between the Kingdom of Mysore and the British East India Company from 1780 to 1784.

questions.Question:
I. His reign saw beginning of a new intercourse between Europe of India
II. Attempted to prohibit traffic in eunuchs
III. Started practices of inter-caste marriages between the families of government officers
IV. Ordered the abolition of inhuman corporal punishments
Which of the above statement (s) is/are correct related to Jahangir?
questions.solution: Solution:		His reign saw beginning of a new intercourse between Europe of India. He attempted to prohibit traffic in eunuchs. He ordered the abolition of inhuman corporal punishments.

questions.Question:
I. Jahangir had set up his court at Allahabad, assumed royal titles and struck coins in his name
II. He banned slaughter of animals on two days in every week viz - Sunday & Thursday.
Which of the above statement (s) is/are correct related to Jahangir?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jahangir had set up his court at Allahabad, assumed royal titles and struck coins in his name. He banned slaughter of animals on two days in every week viz - Sunday & Thursday.

questions.Question:
I. The full name of Jahangir was Nuruddin Md. Jahangir
II. Jahangir had ended a long drawn out struggle with Mewar
III. Mahabat Khan revolted against Jahangir and captured Jahangir and his wife Nurjahan at Lahore
Which of the above statement (s) is/are correct related to Jahangir?
questions.solution: Solution:		The full name of Jahangir was Nuruddin Md. Jahangir. Jahangir had ended a long drawn out struggle with Mewar. Mahabat Khan revolted against Jahangir and captured Jahangir and his wife Nurjahan at Lahore.

questions.Question: Who was the architect who designed "Taj Mahal" ?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ustad Ahmad Lahori, also spelled as 'Ahmad Lahori' was an Iranian architect. He is said to have been chief architect of the Taj Mahal in Agra, India, built between 1632 and 1648 during the ruling period of Mughal emperor Shah Jahan.

questions.Question: The most important political gain to the Mughals during the reign of Shah Jahan was
questions.optionD: expulsion of the Portuguese from Hughli
questions.solution: Solution:		Jahangir gave the title of Shah Jahan to prince Khurram at that very time. But it was, in fact, no remarkable success of the Mughals. Ahmadnagar was not prepared to accept the sovereignty of the Mughals and started fighting against them again. However, peace was again signed between the two in 1621 A.D. by which Ahmadnagar surrendered a part of its territory to the Mughals and also paid rupees eighteen lakhs in cash. Bijapur and Golkunda which had helped Ahmadnagar also paid rupees twelve lakhs and rupees twenty lakhs respectively to the Mughals. Thus, during the reign of Jahangir, Ahmadnagar was weakened and the states of Bijapur and Golkunda were pressurised.

questions.Question: Sher Shah defeated Humayun at
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Chausa was a notable military engagement between the Mughal emperor, Humayun, and the Afghan, Sher Shah Suri. It was fought on 26 June 1539 at Chausa, 10 miles southwest of Buxar in modern-day Bihar, India. Sher Shah was victorious and crowned himself Farīd al-Dīn Shēr Shah.

questions.Question: Humayun lost the Mughal Empire to Sher Shah Suri finally in the battle of
questions.solution: Solution:		On 26 June 1539, Sher Khan faced Humayun in the Battle of Chausa and defeated him. Assuming the title Farid al-Dīn Sher Shah, he defeated Humayun once again at Kannauj in May 1540 and forced him out of India.

questions.Question:
Which of the following are correct regarding Shahjahan?
I. Ousted the Portuguese from Hugli
II. Created the office of Amin for assessment of revenue
III. Kahabat Khan was appointed governor of Lahore
IV. Ali Mardan Khan surrendered Kandhar to Mughals
questions.solution: Solution:		Shahjahan ousted the Portuguese from Hugli. He created the office of Amin for assessment of revenue. Ali Mardan Khan surrendered Kandhar to Mughals.

questions.Question:
Consider the following statement (s) related to the Dara Shikoh
I. Dara Shikoh was the youngest son of Shahjahan.
II. Dara Shikoh was the devotee of Qadiri Silsila.
questions.optionA: Both I and II are correct
questions.optionB: Both I and II are incorrect
questions.solution: Solution:		Dara Shukoh was a follower of the Persian "perennialist" mystic Sarmad Kashani, as well as Lahore's famous Qadiri Sufi saint Hazrat Mian Mir, whom he was introduced to by Mullah Shah Badakhshi (Mian Mir's spiritual disciple and successor).

questions.Question: The Inam land was one which was assigned to
questions.solution: Solution:		During Nizam Rub, the ruler used to give 'inam' (gift of land or land revenue) to scholar and religions person who served them.

questions.Question: All the early Mughal Emperors except __________ were great builders
questions.solution: Solution:		All the early Mughal Emperors except Aurangzeb were great builders.

questions.Question: Noor Jahan was wife of which Mughal Emperor?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nur Jahan (born Mehr-un-Nissa) (31 May 1577 – 17 December 1645) was the twentieth (and last) wife of the Mughal emperor Jahangir.

questions.Question: What does Jahangir mean?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal Prince Salim was the eldest son of Emperor, Akbar. He took the imperial (reign) name 'Jahangir' which means conqueror of the world.

questions.Question: Who built Red Fort?
questions.solution: Solution:		Constructed in 1639 by the fifth Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan as the palace of his fortified capital Shahjahanabad, the Red Fort is named for its massive enclosing walls of red sandstone and is adjacent to the older Salimgarh Fort, built by Islam Shah Suri in 1546 AD.

questions.Question: Babur was born in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Babur (14 February 1483 – 26 December 1530), born Zahir ud-Din Muhammad, was the founder and first Emperor of the Mughal dynasty in India.

questions.Question: Babur came to India originally from
questions.solution: Solution:		Zahiruddin Muhammad was born on February 14, 1483 in the town of Andijan, in the Fergana Valley which is in modern Uzbekistan.

questions.Question: Babur (1526-1530 AD) was the ruler of which dynasty?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mughal Empire was founded by Babur (reigned 1526–1530), a Central Asian ruler who was descended from the Turco-Mongol conqueror Timur (the founder of the Timurid Empire) on his father's side and from Chagatai, the second son of the Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, on his mother's side.

questions.Question: Babur was succeeded to the Mughal throne by
questions.solution: Solution:		Babur married several times. Notable among his sons are Humayun, Kamran Mirza and Hindal Mirza. Babur died in 1530 in Agra and was succeeded by Humayun.

questions.Question: The Mughal leader Babur originally invaded northern India
questions.optionA: To creates a Shiite Muslim state
questions.optionB: Because he was unable to achieve his ambitious goals in central Asia
questions.optionC: To control the trade routes into Southeast Asia
questions.optionD: To defeat his longstanding enemy, the sultan of Delhi
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mughal leader Babur originally invaded northern India because he was unable to achieve his ambitious goals in central Asia.

questions.Question: Who of the following was sent as an ambassador to the royal court of Jahangir by James I, the king of England?
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1614, Roe was elected Member of Parliament for Tamworth. From 1615 to 1618, he was ambassador to the court at Agra, India, of the Great Mughal Ruler, Jahangir. His journal was a valuable source of information for the reign of Jahangir.

questions.Question: Under the Mughal rule the judicial service was formed by
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the Mughal rule the judicial service was formed by Kazis.

questions.Question: The city of Dhillika (Delhi) was founded by the
questions.solution: Solution:		Delhi has a long history and is known to be the city called Indraprastha during the epic times. But historically Delhi's name is associated with a Tomar King named Anangpal, who founded the Red Fort (Lal Kot) in the middle of the 11th century.

questions.Question: Consider the following statements about Sudarshan Lake. Which of them is correct?
questions.optionA: It was constructed by Pushyagupta, the Governor of Saurashtra region during Chandragupta Maurya
questions.optionB: Tushaap constructed a darn on the lake during Ashoka Maurya
questions.optionC: First reconstruction was undertaken by Governor Suvishakh during Saka satrap Rudradaman and 2nd by Chakrapalit during the reign of Skandgupta
questions.solution: Solution:		Sudarshan Lake was constructed by Pushyagupta, the Governor of Saurashtra region during Chandragupta Maurya. Tushaap constructed a darn on the lake during Ashoka Maurya. First reconstruction was undertaken by Governor Suvishakh during Saka satrap Rudradaman and 2nd by Chakrapalit during the reign of Skandgupta.

questions.Question: Which among the following fort was known as the 'Key of Deccan'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Asirgarh fort was built by Muslim emperor Asa Ahir in the peak of the Satpura Ranges, Madhya Pradesh. It is also known as 'Babe Deccan' which means "Key to the Deccan and also Door to South India".

questions.Question: The first Mughal Garden in India had been laid out by
questions.solution: Solution:		The founder of the Mughal empire, Babur, described his favourite type of garden as a charbagh. They use the term bagh, baug, bageecha or bagicha for garden.

questions.Question: Under the Mughal rule the main occupation of the people was
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian agricultural production increased under the Mughal Empire. A variety of crops were grown, including food crops such as wheat, rice, and barley, and non-food cash crops such as cotton, indigo and opium.

questions.Question: Which of the following statement is not correct about Portuguese?
questions.optionA: They brought tobacco cultivation in India
questions.optionB: They spread Catholicism in western and eastern coast of India
questions.optionC: They established first printing press in India at Goa in AD 1556
questions.optionD: The Indian Medicinal Plants was the first scientific work which was published at Andhra Pradesh in 1563
questions.solution: Solution:		The Portuguese were the first Europeans to write scientifically on plants and especially on medicinal plants. Garcia da Orta who published his work Coloquios dos Simples e Drogas da India in 1563 from Goa is considered the pioneer in this field.

questions.Question: The Upanishads were translated by Dara Shikoh in Persian under the title of
questions.solution: Solution:		So'aal o Jawaab bain-e-Laal Daas wa Dara Shikoh (also called Mukaalama-i Baba Laal Daas wa Dara Shikoh) Sirr-e-Akbar (The Great Secret, his translation of the Upanishads in Persian) Persian translations of the Yoga Vasishta and Bhagavad Gita.

questions.Question:
Which statement (s) is/are correct related to Mughal's decline?
I. Mughal's noble were well known for their loyalty but war of successor degenerated the nobility led to the decline of Mughal.
II. Mughal Empire declined due to over decentralization of administration.
questions.solution: Solution:		Prolong war of succession fractured the administrative unit of Mughal’s. Weakness of the Nobility: Mughal’s noble were well known for their loyalty but war of successor degenerated the nobility. The mighty Mughal Empire began to decline after the death of Aurangzeb. The declining prospect of Mughal rule was knelled by quick succession and also war of succession.

questions.Question: Which was the second capital of Akbar?
questions.solution: Solution:		After Akbar's Victory over Rajputana of Chittor and Ranthambor, he shifted his capital from Agra to a new city which he named 'Fatehpur Sikri' (the city of victory).

questions.Question: The innovator of the Revenue settlement during the rule of Akbar was
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Todar Mal was the Finance Minister of the Mughal empire during Akbar's reign. Todarmal was the chief finance minister (Diwan-e-kul) of Mughal Emperor Akbar. He introduced many land revenue reforms like land measurement reforms, Dhasala system and Karoni system.

questions.Question: Akbar saw the sea for the first time in his life at
questions.solution: Solution:		At Cambay, Akbar saw the sea for the first time and rode on it in a boat.

questions.Question: The medieval Hindu ruler who was a contemporary of Akbar, and took the title of Vikramaditya was
questions.solution: Solution:		The medieval Hindu ruler who was a contemporary of Akbar, and took the title of Vikramaditya was Hemachandra (Hemu). Hemu claimed royal status after defeating Akbar's Mughal forces on 7 October 1556 in the Battle of Delhi and assumed the ancient title of Vikramaditya that had been adopted by many Hindu kings in the past. A month later, Hemu was wounded by a chance arrow and captured during the Second Battle of Panipat.

questions.Question: Akbar had got constructed the Buland Darwaza to commemorate his victory of
questions.solution: Solution:		Buland Darwaza, or the "Gate of victory", was built in 1572 A.D. by Mughal emperor Akbar to commemorate his victory over Gujarat. It is the main entrance to the palace at Fatehpur Sikri, which is 43 km from Agra, India.

questions.Question: Who has completed the annexation of Ahmednagar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Khan Jahan Lodi had sold off Balaghat to Ahmadnagar just before the accession of Shah Jahan on the throne. When he revolted, he found shelter in Ahmadnagar. Shah Jahan sent a strong force against Khan Jahan and Ahmadnagar in 1629 A.D. Ahmadnagar, withdrew its support to Khan Jahan but refused to submit itself. The Mughuls could succeed only partially against it.

questions.Question: Which Mughal Emperor fought the battle of Panipat in 1526?
questions.solution: Solution:		The First Battle of Panipat was fought between the invading forces of Babur and the Lodi Empire, which took place on 21 April 1526 in North India. It marked the beginning of the Mughal Empire.

questions.Question: Find out the correct match of the following
questions.solution: Solution:		Bairam Khan was the most prominet military commander-in-chief of the Mughal Army. He was the Guardian, mentor and the teacher of emperor Arkbar.

questions.Question: Under the Mughals the cotton goods were exported to
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the Mughals the main markets was of cotton goods, India's chief export product exported to Africa.

questions.Question: Who discovered a direct sea route to India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The discovery of the sea route to India is the description sometimes used in Europe and among the Portuguese for the first recorded trip made directly from Europe to India via the Atlantic Ocean. It was undertaken under the command of Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama during the reign of King Manuel I in 1497–1499.

questions.Question: Slaves who were in great demand under the Mughals were
questions.solution: Solution:		An extensive demand for slaves was created within India, the demand coming from Mughals. The considerable imports of Abyssinian slaves were in great demand.

questions.Question: Who are credited to a large extent for ending the Mughal rule in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Marathas especially the great maratha rulers Chattrapati Shivaji, Sambhaji, Tarabai and Peshwa Bajirao-I are credited to a large extent for ending the Mughal rule in India.

questions.Question: Akbar's nurse-in-chief was
questions.solution: Solution:		Maham Anga was Akbar's chief nurse prior to his enthronement at age thirteen as Mughal emperor in 1556.

questions.Question: The main outlet for foreign trade during Akbar's reign was the port of
questions.solution: Solution:		During his reign they were the most powerful at sea. Trade at Surat, the main port of Mughal India. Gujarat that emerged as the leading outlet at a given time.

questions.Question: Akbar's teacher was
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar was very tolerant in his religious views. In his childhood he was impressed by the liberal religious ideas of his teacher, Abdul Latif.

questions.Question: The original name of Tansen, the greatest musician of the court of Akbar, was
questions.solution: Solution:		Tansen (c. 1500 – 1586), also referred to as Tan Sen or Ramtanu Pandey, was a prominent figure of North Indian (Hindustani) classical music. Born in a Hindu family, he learned and perfected his art in the northwest region of modern Madhya Pradesh.

questions.Question: Akbar (1556-1605 AD) was the ruler of which dynasty?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abu'l-Fath Jalal-ud-din Muhammad Akbar (October 1542– 27 October 1605), popularly known as Akbar I, also as Akbar the Great (Akbar-i-azam), was the third Mughal emperor, who reigned from 1556 to 1605.

questions.Question: Which of the following state was not the victim of "The Subsidiary Alliance System"?
questions.solution: Solution:		Satara state was not the victim of "The Subsidiary Alliance System".

questions.Question: Which state was the first victim of "The Subsidiary Alliance System"?
questions.solution: Solution:		‘The Nizam of Hyderabad’ was the first victim of this policy. In AD 1798 it detached the Nizam from the French and also forbade having alliances with Maratha without British consent.

questions.Question: The Battle of Haldighati (1576) was a fight between Rajput and Mughal forces. Who led the Mughal forces?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Haldighati was a battle fought on 18 June 1576 between cavalry and archers supporting the Rana of Mewar, Maharana Pratap; and the Mughal emperor Akbar's forces, led by Man Singh I of Amber.

questions.Question: Which Pratihara ruler had the famous poet, Rajasekhara, at his court?
questions.solution: Solution:		The famous poet Rajasekhara lived in his court, and subsequently in the court of his son Mahipala. He was the author of Kavyamimansa, which contains a wealth of geographical data. Mahipala was the last important ruler of the Pratihara dynasty.

questions.Question: Painting reached its highest level of development during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal Paintings reached its Zenith during the reign of Mughal Emperor Jahangir. He patronised many great painters including Mansoou, Abul Hasan, Daswant and Basawan.

questions.Question: The designation 'amil' during Akbar's reign denoted a
questions.solution: Solution:		The designation 'amil' during Akbar's reign denoted aRevenue official.

questions.Question: Akbar's son and successor Salim, on becoming the emperor, assumed the name of
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar's son and successor Salim, on becoming the emperor, assumed the name of Nuruddin Muhammad Jahangir.

questions.Question: Akbar defeated Durgawati and captured
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1562 CE, Akbar defeated Baz Bahadur and brought the region of Malwa under Mughal dominion. Simultaneously, Asaf Khan, a Mughal general, conquered Rewa, which lay north of Rani’s kingdom. Thus, Garha-Mandla now touched the boundaries of both Rewa and Malwa, which were under the Mughals. An attack from either of them was imminent.

questions.Question: The Akbar of Kashmir who reconstructed and rehabilitated all the temples and asked Jonaraja to continue further Kalhana's Rajatarangini was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Akbar of Kashmir who reconstructed and rehabilitated all the temples and asked Jonaraja to continue further Kalhana's Rajatarangini wasZain-ul-Abidin.

questions.Question: Hakim Mirza, the younger brother of Akbar was the viceroy of
questions.solution: Solution:		Shahzada Mirza Muhammad Hakim, sometimes known simply as Mirza Hakim, short: Mirza, was the second son of Mughal emperor Humayun. He ruled Kabul in Afghanistan, and often conflicted with his elder brother emperor Akbar. Mirza Hakim later on mended ways with Emperor Akbar. He is the son of Mah Chuchak Begum. He is known for writing Tajdar-e-Haram.

questions.Question: The stone railing which Aurangzeb ordered to remove was presented to Keshav Rai Temple by
questions.solution: Solution:		By order of Aurangzeb he had also forcibly removed, in 1666, the stone railing presented to the Keshav Rai temple by Dara Shikoh.

questions.Question: What is the full name of Aurangzeb?
questions.solution: Solution:		Muhi-ud-Din Muhammad also known as Aurangzeb or by his title Alamgir was the sixth emperor of the Mughal Empire. He ruled over most of the Indian subcontinent. His reign lasted for 49 years from 1658 until his death in 1707.

questions.Question:
Which of the following temples were destroyed by Aurangzeb?
I. Somnath temple
II. Vishwanath temple
III. Keshav Rai temple
IV. Meenakshi temple
questions.solution: Solution:		Temples that were destroyed by Aurangzeb are Somnath temple, Vishwanath temple and Keshav Rai temple.

questions.Question: Which of the following statement is related to the Mughal emperor Aurangzeb?
questions.optionA: Replaced many Hindu temples with mosques
questions.optionD: Presided over an era of religious harmony
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal emperor Aurangzeb replaced many Hindu temples with mosques. The original Kashi Vishwanath Temple was demolished by Aurangzeb, the sixth Mughal emperor who constructed the Gyanvapi Mosque atop the original Hindu temple. Kashi Vishwanath was among the most renowned Hindu temples of India. Even today the pillars and the structure of the original temple can be clearly seen.

questions.Question: Which Sikh guru was executed by Aurangzeb?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Guru was summoned to Delhi by Aurangzeb on a pretext, but when he arrived, he was offered, "to abandon his faith, and convert to Islam". Guru Tegh Bahadur refused, and he and his associates were arrested. He was executed on 11 November 1675 in public in Chandni Chowk, Delhi.

questions.Question: Humayun was born in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Humayun was born on 17 March 1508, in Kabul, Mughal Empire (present-day Afghanistan), to Babur, the founder of the Mughal dynasty and his wife Maham Begum.

questions.Question: Humayun died in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		On the evening of 21 Jan 1556, Humayun was walking in the terrace of his library at Sher Mandal in Delhi. While descending the steps, he heard the announcement for the evening prayer. He stood still upon the occasion and sat down on the second step till the proclamation was ended. When he was going to rise, he supported himself on a staff, which unfortunately slipped upon the marble, and he fell headlong from the top to the bottom of the stair. He was taken up insensible and laid upon his bed. He died on 24 Jan, at the age of fifty-one, after a reign of twenty-five years, in Kabul and India.

questions.Question: Humayun Nama was written by
questions.solution: Solution:		The History of Humayun: Humayun Nama was written by Gul-badan Begam, Humayun' s sister. Gul-Badan Begum (1523 - 1603), was daughter of Zaheruddin Muhammad Babur of India. She wrote Humayun nama at the behest of her nephew and at the emperor of India Jalal-ud-din Muhammad Akbar.

questions.Question: When Humayun was in exile Koh-i-noor Diamond was with
questions.solution: Solution:		When Humayun was in exile Koh-i-noor Diamond was with Shah Tahmasp of Persia.

questions.Question: Who defeated Humayun in the battle of Chausa?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Chausa (25 June 1539) took place between Mughal Emperor Humayun and Sher Shah Suri (Sher Khan). In this battle Humayun got defeated.

questions.Question: In the Mughal period the registers of the agricultural lands were maintained by
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Mughal period the registers of the agricultural lands were maintained by Qanungo.

questions.Question: The Mir Bakshi of the Mughal Emperors was the head of
questions.solution: Solution:		The head of the military was called the mir bakshi, appointed from among the leading nobles of the court. The mir bakshi was in charge of intelligence gathering, and also made recommendations to the emperor for military appointments and promotions.

questions.Question: In the Battle of Haldighati the Mughal troops were commanded by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Haldighati was a battle fought on 18 June 1576 between cavalry and archers supporting the Rana of Mewar, Maharana Pratap; and the Mughal emperor Akbar's forces, led by Man Singh I of Amber.

questions.Question: Second battle of Panipat was fought between which two armies?
questions.solution: Solution:		Second Battle of Panipat was fought between Akbar & Hemu in 1556 in which Hemu was defeated. The original name of Hemu was Hemchand he was also known as 'Vikramaditya' & he was the 14th ruler who took the title of Vikramaditya.

questions.Question: Which Pala ruler founded the famous Vikramashila University for the Buddhists'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Vikramashila was founded by Pāla king Dharmapala in the late 8th or early 9th century. It prospered for about four centuries before it was destroyed by Bakhtiyar Khilji along with the other major centres of Buddhism in India around 1193.

questions.Question: Akbar was enthroned in a garden at
questions.solution: Solution:		The town has recorded essentialness as Mughal Emperor Akbar, was enthroned in a garden close to the Kalanaur by Bairam Khan.

questions.Question: The only Hindu Courtier of Akbar who accepted Din-i-Ilahi was
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Birbal was the only Hindu to adopt Din-i-Ilahi, the religion founded by Akbar.

questions.Question: Ramayana was translated into Persian at Akbar's court by whom?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ramayana was translated by Mulla Abdul Qadir Badayuni into Persian.

questions.Question: Of the so-called 'Nine Gems of the Court of Akbar' the one who was a reputed poet of Hindi, was
questions.solution: Solution:		Khanzada Mirza Khan Abdul Rahim Khan-e-Khana (17 December 1556 – 1627) also known as baba Rahim was a poet who lived during the rule of Mughal emperor Akbar. He was one of the nine important ministers (dewan) in his court, also known as the Navaratnas.

questions.Question: Which was the second capital of Akbar?
questions.solution: Solution:		After Akbar's victory over Rajputanas of Chittor and Ranthambore, he shifted his capital from Agra to a new city which named 'Fatehpur Sikri' (the city of victory).

questions.Question: The art of painting in the Mughal age was __________ in origin
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal painting is that particular style of South Asian painting which generally confines miniatures either as book illustrations or as single works to be kept in albums, which emerged from Persian miniature painting (itself largely of Chinese origin), with Indian Muslim, Hindu, Jain, and Buddhist influences, and developed largely in the court of the Mughal Empire of the 16th to 18th centuries.

questions.Question: Under the Mughals one of the main imports was
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the Mughals one of the main imports wasraw silk.

questions.Question: Who built Imambara and Rumi Darwaza?
questions.solution: Solution:		Rumi Darwaza was built by the fourth Nawab of Lucknow, Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula and is believed to be identical to an old gate in Istanbul called Bab-i-Hümayun, and so is also sometimes referred to as Turkish Gate. The 60 feet high gate is now considered an architectural marvel, but it built for a noble purpose.

questions.Question: Which one of the following Mughal buildings is said to possess the unique feature of being exactly equal in length and breadth?
questions.solution: Solution:		Taj Mahal was built by Mughal Emperor Shahjahan in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz. It was designed by Ustad Ahmad Lahauri. The dome of Taj Mahal has exactly same height and the lenght of base i.e. 35 metres.

questions.Question: Historian Abdul Hamid Lahori was in the court of
questions.solution: Solution:		Abdul Hamid Lahori (died 1654) was a traveller and historian during the period of Shah Jahan who later became a court historian of Shah Jahan.

questions.Question: Who had succeeded Mir Jumla as governor of Bengal in the reign of Aurangzeb?
questions.solution: Solution:		Shaista Khan succeeded Mir Jumla as the governor of Bengal after his death. He gave personal attention to the problem of south Bengal, where the Magh (Arakanese) pirates, in conjunction with Portuguese pirates, had been terrorizing the area up to Dacca (capital of Bengal) from their headquarters at Chittagong.

questions.Question: During the reign of Aurangzeb, Rajaram was a
questions.solution: Solution:		Rajaram Raje Bhosale (24 February 1670 – 3 March 1700 Sinhagad) was the younger son of Maratha ruler Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, and half-brother of Sambhaji Maharaj. He took over the Maratha Empire as its third Chhatrapati after his brother's death at the hands of the Mughal emperor, Aurangzeb in 1689.

questions.Question: On behalf of Aurangzeb Cooch Behar was seized by
questions.solution: Solution:		On behalf of Aurangzeb Cooch Behar was seized byMir Jumla.

questions.Question: Aurangzeb put his father under house arrest in Agra Fort
questions.solution: Solution:		Shah Jahan recovered from his illness, but Aurangzeb put his father under house arrest in Agra Fort from July 1658 until his death in January 1666.

questions.Question: Of the following who did not revolt against Aurangzeb?
questions.solution: Solution:		Shayista Khan did not revolt against Aurangzeb.

questions.Question: Which of the following statement is not true about "Doctrine of Lapse"?
questions.optionA: It was started by Lord Dalhousie
questions.optionB: It was in operations between 1848 and 1856
questions.optionC: Nagpur was the first state annexed under this rule
questions.optionD: Satara, jaipur, Jhansi and Nagpur states were annexed under this rule
questions.solution: Solution:		Satara was the first state annexed under this rule.

questions.Question: "Mansabdars" in Mughal period were
questions.optionC: Those who had to give revenue
questions.solution: Solution:		"Mansabdars" in Mughal period were Landlords and zamindars.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not true about Tipu Sultan?
questions.optionA: He was a Great admirer of Jagadguru Sankracharya of Sringeri
questions.optionC: He died during the fourth Anglo-Mysore war
questions.optionD: He laid the foundation of Krishnaraj Sagar Dam on Cauvery
questions.solution: Solution:		In the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War, the imperial forces of the British East India Company were supported by the Nizam of Hyderabad and Marathas. They defeated Tipu, and he was killed on 4 May 1799 while defending his fort of Srirangapatna.

questions.Question: During the Mughal period the main source of Imperial revenue was
questions.solution: Solution:		Indian agricultural production increased under the Mughal Empire. A variety of crops were grown, including food crops such as wheat, rice, and barley, and non-food cash crops such as cotton, indigo and opium.

questions.Question:
I. Jahangir promulgated twelve edicts for the general welfare and better government to mark his coronation
II. Jahangir composed verses in Persian and sang Hindi lyrics
Which of the above statement (s) is/are correct?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jahangir promulgated twelve edicts for the general welfare and better government to mark his coronation. Jahangir composed verses in Persian and sang Hindi lyrics.

questions.Question: The French East India Company was founded in
questions.solution: Solution:		Jean-Baptiste Colbert founded the French East India Company in 1664.

questions.Question: __________was the first Mughal Emperor to acquire Koh-i-noor diamond
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar was the first Mughal Emperor to acquire Koh-i-noor diamond.

questions.Question: The foreign traveller who visited Indian during the Mughal Period and who left us and expert description of the Peacock Throne, was
questions.solution: Solution:		A foreign traveller who visited India during the Mughal period, was a jeweller and has left us an expert's description of the Peacock Throne, was Travernier.

questions.Question: The treaty of Allahabad took place between __________
questions.optionA: Shuja-ud-daulah, Robert Clive and Shah Alam II
questions.optionB: Shuja-ud-daulah, Mir jafar and Shah Alam II
questions.optionC: Shuja-ud-daulah, Wajid Ali Shah and Shah Alam II
questions.solution: Solution:		The Treaty of Allahabad was signed on 12 August 1765, between the Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II, son of the late Emperor Alamgir II, and Robert Clive, of the East India Company, as a result of the Battle of Buxar of 22 October 1764.

questions.Question: During the Mughal period there was continuous emigration of the __________ to places ruled by Hindu Rajas
questions.solution: Solution:		During the Mughal period there was continuous emigration of the poor to places ruled by Hindu Rajas.

questions.Question: Jahangir (1605-1627 AD) was the ruler of which dynasty?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mirza Nur-ud-din Beig Muhammad Khan Salim, known by his imperial name Jahangir (31 August 1569 – 28 October 1627), was the fourth Mughal Emperor who ruled from 1605 until his death in 1627.

questions.Question:
Which of the following statement (s) is/are correct related to Mughal Emperor Jahangir?
I. Jahangir claimed that he could distinguish the work of different artists in a single picture.
II. Painting was at its climax during his reign.
questions.solution: Solution:		Jahangir claimed that he could distinguish the work of different artists in a single picture. Painting was at its climax during his reign.

questions.Question: Which of the undermentioned facts about Taj Mahal is not correct?
questions.optionB: It was built by Shah Jahan
questions.optionC: It is situated outside Agra Fort
questions.optionD: The names of artisans who builtd it are engraved on it
questions.solution: Solution:		The names of artisans who build it are not engraved on it.

questions.Question: The Ibadat Khana was a meeting house built by which Mughal Emperor?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Ibadat Khana (House of Worship) was a meeting house built in 1575 CE by the Mughal Emperor Akbar (r. 1556–1605) at Fatehpur Sikri to gather spiritual leaders of different religious grounds so as to conduct a discussion on the teachings of the respective religious leaders.

questions.Question: The first invasion of India by Sultan Mahmud Ghazni was in
questions.solution: Solution:		Mahmud of Ghazni first invaded modern Afghanistan and Pakistan in 1000 AD. He defeated Hindu shahi kingdom ruler Jaya Pala, who killed himself later, and his son Ananda Pala became his successor. 1006 : Ghazni invaded Multan.

questions.Question: In 1542 Akbar was born at
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar (Abu'l-Fath Jalal ud-din Muhammad Akbar, 15 October 1542 – 1605) was the 3rd Mughal Emperor. He was born in Umerkot,(now Pakistan). He was the son of 2nd Mughal Emperor Humayun. Akbar became the king in 1556 at the age of 13 when his father died.

questions.Question: Which of the following was built by Akbar to commemorate his conquest of Khandesh in Gujarat?
questions.solution: Solution:		Buland Darwaza (The Gate of Magnificience) was built by Mughal Emperor Akbar in 1601 at Fatehpur Sikri (U.P.). It was built by Akbar to commemorate his victory over Khandesh in Gujarat.

questions.Question: Who was the regent of Akbar in his early days?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bairam Khan also Bayram Khan ( c. 18 January 1501 – c. 31 January 1561) was an important military commander, later commander-in-chief of the Mughal army, a powerful statesman and regent at the court of the Mughal Emperors, Humayun and Akbar.

questions.Question: What was the age of Akbar at the time of his coronation at Kalanaur?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal Emperor Akbar aseended the throne at the age of thirteen in the year 1556 A.D.

questions.Question: Two women who, while conducting the affairs of their states faced Akbar's wars of conquest were Rani Durgawati and Chand Bibi (or Sultana), respectively of
questions.solution: Solution:		Two women who, while conducting the affairs of their states faced Akbar's wars of conquest were Rani Durgawati and Chand Bibi (or Sultana), respectively of Gondwana and Ahmadnagar.

questions.Question: Which of the following Mughal monarchs has vividly described Indian flora & fauna, seasons, fruits etc. in his diary?
questions.solution: Solution:		Both Mughal Emperor Babur and Emperor Jahangir have visibly described Indian flora, fauna and season & fruit in his diary. But option 'C' is more accurate.

questions.Question: Under the Mughals the Governor was popularly known as
questions.solution: Solution:		The principal officer was the governor, called sipah salar under Akbar and nazim under his successors, but popularly known as subahdar and later only as subah.

questions.Question: Who was the last Mughal emperor?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abu Zafar Sirajuddin Muhammad Bahadur Shah Zafar, also known as Bahadur Shah or Bahadur Shah II (October 1775 - 7 November 1862) was the last of the Mughal emperors in India, as well as the last ruler of the Timurid Dynasty. He was the son of Akbar Shah II and Lalbai, who was a Hindu Rajput.

questions.Question: Who among the following rulers abolished Jiziya?
questions.solution: Solution:		Jizya was abolished by the third Mughal emperor Akbar, in 1564. It was finally abolished in 1579.

questions.Question: What is the correct order (first to last) of states annexed under the policy of "Doctrine of Lapse"?
questions.solution: Solution:		The company took over the princely states of Satara (1848), Jaitpur and Sambalpur (1849), Nagpur and Jhansi (1854), Tore and Arcot (1855) and Udaipur (Chhattisgarh) under the terms of the doctrine of lapse. Oudh (1856) is widely believed to have under the Doctrine of Lapse.

questions.Question: Where is the Bara Imambara located?
questions.solution: Solution:		Bara Imambara, also known as Asafi Imambara is an imambara complex in Lucknow, India built by Asaf-ud-Daula, Nawab of Awadh in 1784. Bara means big.

questions.Question: Under the Mughals the jizya was collected from
questions.solution: Solution:		Jizya tax was protection money. Muslims have been charging it not only from hindus in the past but from any non-muslim citizens in a territory they rule.

questions.Question: The first Mughal emperor of India was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mughal Empire was founded by Babur (reigned 1526–1530), a Central Asian ruler who was descended from the Turco-Mongol conqueror Timur (the founder of the Timurid Empire) on his father's side and from Chagatai, the second son of the Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, on his mother's side.

questions.Question: The peacock throne was constructed by the Mughal Emperor
questions.solution: Solution:		The Peacock Throne was a jewelled throne built by Emperor Shah Jahan in the early 17th century. It was kept in the Diwan- e- Khas of the Red Fort in Delhi.

questions.Question: The writer of Ram Charit Manas, Tulsidas, was related to which ruler?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ram Charit Manas is considered by national and International scholars as one of the greatest pieces of literature ever written in the world. Tulsidas was a contemporary of Mughal emperor Akbar. But Hindutva forces have generally pitted Tulsidas against Akbar.

questions.Question: The Mughal queen, whose name was inscribed on the coins and on all royal farmans as well as attached to the imperial signature was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mughal queen, whose name was inscribed on the coins and on all royal farmans as well as attached to the imperial signature was Nur Jahan.

questions.Question: The Mughal troops were largely drawn from
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mansabdar was a military unit within the administrative system of the Mughal Empire introduced by Akbar. The word mansab is of Arabic origin meaning rank or position. The system, hence, determined the rank of a government official and also other military generals. Every civil and military officer was given a 'mansab' and different which could be increased by ten were used for ranking officers.

questions.Question: The Mughal painting reached its zenith during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mughal paintings reached its zenith during the reign of Emperor Jahangir. He patronized many great painters like Mansoon, Abul Hasan, Daswant and Basawan.

questions.Question: Mughal painting reached its zenith during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mughal paintings reached its zenith during the reign of Emperor Jahangir. He patronized many great painters like Mansoon, Abul Hasan, Daswant and Basawan.

questions.Question: Who among the following Mughal emperors, brought about the fall of Sayyid Brothers?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sayyid Brothers Abdulla Khan (Wazir) and Hussain Ali Khan (Mir Bakshi) were the generals in Mughal army. They became very influential after the death of Emperor Aurangzeb. When Mughal Emperor Muhammad Shah ascended the throne, he took even the full control and got the killed. They also known as "King Makers".

questions.Question: When Aurangzeb proceeded against Golconda it was ruled by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Siege of Golconda occurred in January 1687, when Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb led his forces to besiege the Qutb Shahi dynasty at Golconda Fort (also known as the Diamond Capital of its time) and was home to the Kollur Mine. The ruler of Golconda was the well entrenched Abul Hasan Qutb Shah.

questions.Question: Assuming the title of Alamgir, Aurangzeb crowned himself as Emperor on July 21, 1658 at
questions.solution: Solution:		When Shah Jahan fell ill in September 1657, Aurangzeb challenged Dara, defeated him, imprisoned their father, and assumed imperial authority on July 21, 1658. After liquidating his three brothers, he crowned himself emperor of India, assuming the title Alamgir (Conqueror of the World) at Delhi on June 5, 1659.

questions.Question: Aurangzeb (1658-1707 AD) was the ruler of which dynasty?
questions.solution: Solution:		The last of the great Mughals was Aurangzeb (r. 1658-1707), who seized the throne by killing all his brothers and imprisoning his own father. Aurangzeb was the third son of the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan; his mother was Mumtaz Mahal, who is buried in the Taj Mahal.

questions.Question: Aurangzeb died in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurangzeb died in the year 3 March 1707 (aged 88) Ahmednagar, India.

questions.Question: Aurangzeb was the son of
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurangzeb was born on 3 November 1618, in Dahod, Gujarat. He was the third son and sixth child of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal.

questions.Question: Akbar had incorporated some principles of social reforms in the Din-i-illahi. Which of the following social reforms did not form part of Din-i- illahi?
questions.solution: Solution:		Rejection of seclusion of women social reforms did not form part of din-i- ilahi.

questions.Question: Which of the following statement is not related to the Akbar's reign?
questions.optionA: Religious toleration for Hindus and Sikhs
questions.optionB: A syncretic religion, called "divine faith," which stressed loyalty to the emperor
questions.optionC: A centralized administrative structure with ministers appointed to regional provinces
questions.optionD: Education and basic rights for Indian women
questions.solution: Solution:		Education and basic rights for Indian women is not related to the Akbar's reign.

questions.Question: To bring Hindu-Muslim unity, Akbar
questions.solution: Solution:		To bring Hindu-Muslim unity, Akbar prohibited cow-killing. He banned killing of animals. He stopped eating meat for many months.

questions.Question: Who were 'Jagirdars' during the reign of Akbar?
questions.optionB: Officials of state who were given jagir in place of cash pay
questions.solution: Solution:		This feudal system of land ownership is referred to as the jagirdar system. The system was introduced by the Sultans of Delhi from the 13th century onwards, was later adopted by the Mughal Empire, and continued under the British East India Company.

questions.Question: The only Hindu noble at the court of Akbar to accept the Din-i-llahi was
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Birbal was the only Hindu to adopt Din-i-Ilahi, the religion founded by Akbar.

questions.Question: In the war of succession who had supported Aurangzeb?
questions.solution: Solution:		Roshanara's rise to power began when she successfully foiled a plot by her father and Dara Shikoh to kill Aurangzeb. According to history, Shah Jahan sent a letter of invitation to Aurangzeb to visit Delhi, in order to peacefully resolve the family crisis. In truth, however, Shah Jahan planned to capture, imprison and kill Aurangazeb in prison as he viewed his third son as a serious threat to the throne. When Roshanara got wind of her father's plots, she sent a messenger to Aurangzeb, outlining their father's true intentions, and warning Aurangazeb to stay away from Delhi. Aurangzeb was extremely grateful to Roshanara for her timely warning. When the war of succession was resolved in favour of Aurangzeb, she quickly became a powerful figure at court.

questions.Question: During Aurangzeb's reign, which of the following were not included in his government?
questions.solution: Solution:		During his reign, the Mughal Empire extended from the Himalayas to Karnataka and Gujarat to Bengal. However he faced lot of rebels from the Jat, Maratha as well as Sikh community. Marathas were not included in Aurangzeb's government.

questions.Question:
I. Aurangzeb abolished Rahdari, Pandari and Pilgrim tax.
II. Aurangzeb discontinued the practice of inscribing the Kalima on the coins.
Which of the above statements is/are correct related to Aurangzeb?
questions.solution: Solution:		Formerly Kalima used to be embossed on the coins. This practice was abandoned by Aurangzeb as it was un-Islamic.

questions.Question: The most decisive battle between the forces of Dara and Aurangzeb (in the war of Succession) was fought at
questions.solution: Solution:		Battle of Samugarh, Jang-e-Samugarh, (May 29, 1658), was a decisive battle in the struggle for the throne during the Mughal war of succession (1658–1659) between the sons of the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan after the emperor's serious illness in September 1657.

questions.Question: Bibi Ka Maqbara was erected by __________ at Aurangabad and is a replica of the Taj Mahal
questions.solution: Solution:		The Bibi Ka Maqbara (English:"Tomb of the Lady") is a tomb located in Aurangabad, Maharashtra, India. It was built by Mughal emperor Aurangzeb's son Azam Shah in the memory of his mother (posthumously known as Rabia-ud-Daurani).

questions.Question: Which Mughal ruler's reign has been described as the golden age of medieval art and architecture?
questions.solution: Solution:		The age of Shah Jahan(January 1628-July 1658) is considered to be the golden age in Mughal Empire because during his reign there was peace in the country.There were no foreign threats. He did a lot of work for the welfare of people like he constructed roads, canals, sarais etc.

questions.Question: Which one of the following traders first came to India during the Mughal period?
questions.solution: Solution:		Portuguese traders first came to India during the Mughal period.

questions.Question: Who among the following Mughal Emperor became the first pensioner of the East India Company?
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar II (22 April 1760 – 28 September 1837), also known as Akbar Shah II, was the penultimate Mughal emperor of India. He reigned from 1806 to 1837.

questions.Question: The famous Mughal General who conquered Assam, Chittagong, etc. in the north-east was
questions.solution: Solution:		The famous Mughal General who conquered Assam, Chittagong, etc. in the north-east was Mir Jumla.

questions.Question: The Mughal government can be described as an/a
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mughal government was a centralized despotism. In such a system everything depended upon the personality and character of the monarch.

questions.Question: In Akbar's regime,__________  was the military head
questions.solution: Solution:		The head of the military was called the mir bakshi, appointed from among the leading nobles of the court. The mir bakshi was in charge of intelligence gathering, and also made recommendations to the emperor for military appointments and promotions.

questions.Question: The fortress of Asirgarh was under the rule of __________ when Akbar besieged it
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar occupied Burhanpur and besieged Asirgarh Fort in 1599, and took it on 17 January 1601, when Miran Bahadur Shah refused to submit Khandesh.

questions.Question: Who wrote Akbarnama?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abdul Fazal was one of the navratnas at Akbar's court. He wrote 'Akbamama' which is the official history of Akbar's reign.

questions.Question: What was the name of the Hall of Worship constructed by Akbar?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Ibadat Khana (House of Worship) was a meeting house built in 1575 CE by the Mughal Emperor Akbar (r. 1556–1605) at Fatehpur Sikri to gather spiritual leaders of different religious grounds so as to conduct a discussion on the teachings of the respective religious leaders.

questions.Question: Who was appointed by Akbar as his Court Musician?
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar considered Miyan Tansen as a Navaratnas (nine jewels), and gave him the title Mian, an honorific, meaning learned man. Tansen was a composer, musician and vocalist, to whom a large number of compositions have been attributed in northern regions of the Indian subcontinent.

questions.Question: Who introduced Mansabdari system in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Mansabdari system was the administrative system introduced by Akbar in Mughal Empire during 1571. The word 'Mansab' is of Arabic origin meaning rank or position. Hence, Mansabdari was a system of ranking the government officials and determined their civil & military duties, along with their renumerations.

questions.Question: Which of the following pair is incorrect?
questions.solution: Solution:		Birbal was one of the nine Jews in the court of Akbar, he was not the finance minister. Todarmal was the finance minister of Akbar.

questions.Question: Who among the following was an illiterate?
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar remained illiterate and uneducated all his life. He had to occupy the throne at the early age of 13 years after the untimely death of his father Humayun. The responsibilities of the Great Mughal Empire never allowed him the time to educate himself.

questions.Question: Which one of the following was the cause of disintegration of the Mughal Empire?
questions.optionA: War of succession among sons of Aurangzeb
questions.optionB: Attacks of Nadir Shah and Ahmad Shah Abdali
questions.optionC: Revolts of various communities like Jats, Sikhs, Rajputs etc.
questions.optionD: All of the above mentioned factors contributed to the downfall of the Mughal Empire.
questions.solution: Solution:		War of succession among sons of Aurangzeb. 9Attacks of Nadir Shah and Ahmad Shah Abdali. Revolts of various communities like Jats, Sikhs, Rajputs etc. All of the above mentioned factors contributed to the downfall of the Mughal Empire.

questions.Question: The well-known painting showing the arrival at the Mughal Court of the great singer Tansen exhibits
questions.optionD: The fusion of the Mughal and Hindu Styles
questions.solution: Solution:		The well-known painting of the arrival of Tansen, the legendary singer at the court of Akbar, shows the fusion of this Persian and Hindu styles of art.

questions.Question: The battle between Babur and Rana Sanga was fought at
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Khanwa was fought near the village of Khanwa, in Bharatpur District of Rajasthan, on March 16, 1527. It was fought between the invading forces of the first Mughal Emperor Babur and the Rajput forces led by Rana Sanga of Mewar, after the Battle of Panipat.

questions.Question:
Assertion (A): Babur won the first Battle of Panipat.
Reason (R): Babur was the first to introduce the use of cannons in India.
questions.optionA: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.optionB: Both A and R are true but R is not a correct explanation of A
questions.optionC: A is true but R is false
questions.optionD: A is false but R is true
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1526, the First Battle of Panipat saw the introduction of massed artillery tactics to Indian warfare. Under the guidance of Ottoman gun master Ustad Ali Quli, Babur deployed cannons behind a screening row of carts.

questions.Question: Babur's autobiography, called Tuzuk-i-Baburi or Baburnama, which is reckoned among "the most enthralling and romantic works in the literature of all times" is written in
questions.solution: Solution:		Babar's autobiography, called Tuzuk-i-Baburi or Baburnama, which is reckoned among “the most enthralling and romantic works in the literature of all times" is written in Turki.

questions.Question: Babur was originally the ruler of
questions.solution: Solution:		Babur was born in Andijan, in the Fergana Valley, in modern Uzbekistan. He was the eldest son of Umar Sheikh Mirza, governor of Fergana and great grandson of Timur the Great.

questions.Question: Where did Babur died?
questions.solution: Solution:		Babur died in 1530 in Agra and was succeeded by Humayun. He was first buried in Agra but, as per his wishes, his mortal remains were moved to Kabul reburied.

questions.Question: Under the Mughals, the Police duties in urban areas were entrusted to the officers known as
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the Mughals, all police duties in the cities and towns were entrusted to the 'Kotwal'. He was essentially an urban officer, being chief on the city police.

questions.Question: Which of the following Mughal ruler who tried to create affinity between Sikh and Maratha by granted the right to collect Sardesh Mukhi of Deccan but not Chauth to the Marathas?
questions.solution: Solution:		Muazzam tried to create affinity between Sikh and Maratha. He granted the right to collect Sardesh Mukhi of Deccan but not Chauth to the Marathas.

questions.Question: The Battle of Buxar fought between __________
questions.optionA: The English, the Nawab of Bengal and the French
questions.optionB: Mir Kasim, the Nawab of Bengal, Nawab of Oudh and Shah Alam II, The Mughal Emperor
questions.optionC: Akbar II, the Nawab of Bengal and Nawab of Oudh
questions.optionD: Akbar II, the Nawab of Bengal and the Marathas
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Buxar was fought in 1764, between the British and the armies of Mir Qasim, Mughal Emperor Shah Alam-II and Shuja-ud-Daulah , Nawab of Awadh in Buxar(in Bihar). The battle was won by forces of British East India company. The British won this battle under the command of Hector Munro.

questions.Question: First Anglo Sikh War fought between __________
questions.solution: Solution:		The First Anglo-Sikh War was fought between the Sikh Empire and the East India Company between 1845 and 1846. It resulted in partial subjugation of the Sikh kingdom and cession of Jammu and Kashmir as a separate princely state under British suzerainty.

questions.Question: Who among the following was also known as 'Zinda Pir'?
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurangzeb was called “Zinda Pir”or “Living Saint ” in Mughal India. He banned on Nauroj festival, Tuladan, Jharokha etc, he restarted Jizya Tax.

questions.Question: Which of the following forts was not built by Akbar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Gwalior Fort was built by Raja Man Sing Tomar in 8th century. It consists of one defensive structure and two main palaces ( Gujrat Mahal and Man Mandir ).

questions.Question: A renowned Jain scholar who was greatly honoured by Akbar was
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar invited Bhattarak Harvijay Suri the main exponent of Jain Swetambara sect.

questions.Question: Who of the following was the biographer of Akbar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Ain-i-Akbari (The constitution of Akbar) is the third volume of 'Akbarnama' (the book of Akbar) was written by Abul Fazal. He was the court poet of Mughal Emperor Akbar.

questions.Question: Which Rajput dynasty had not surrendered to Akbar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sisodiya dynasty that ruled mewar did not surrender to emperor Akbar until and unless Jahangir defeated Rana Pratap's Son.

questions.Question: The greatest historian of the reign of Akbar, who wrote Akbarnama and Ain-i-Akbari, was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Akbarnama which translates to Book of Akbar, is the official chronicle of the reign of Akbar, the third Mughal Emperor (r. 1556–1605), commissioned by Akbar himself by his court historian and biographer, Abu'l-Fazl ibn Mubarak who was one of the nine jewels in Akbar's court. He had also written Ain-i-Akbari.

questions.Question: Birbal was an advisor in the court of?
questions.solution: Solution:		Birbal is a famous historical character and he was a court jester in the court of Mughal Emperor Jalaluddin Mohammed Akbar. He was one among the nine jewels or 'Nav Ratnas' in the court of Akbar. He was in the inner council of advisors of Akbar's administration.

questions.Question: Which Mughal emperor was a great musician, a great patron of Hindustani Music and was popularly known as Rangila?
questions.solution: Solution:		Muhammad Shah was a great patron of the arts, including musical, cultural and administrative developments. His pen-name was Sada Rangila ("ever joyous") and he is often referred to as "Muhammad Shah Rangila", also sometimes as "Bahadur Shah Rangila" after his grand father Bahadur Shah I.

questions.Question: When was the battle of Buxar fought?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Battle of Buxar was fought on 22 October 1764 between the forces under the command of the British East India Company, led by Hector Munro, and the combined armies of Mir Qasim, Nawab of Bengal till 1763; the Nawab of Awadh; and the Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II.

questions.Question: Which European power was the last who reached India?
questions.solution: Solution:		France was the last of the major European maritime powers of the 17th century to enter the East India trade.

questions.Question: "Din-i-Ilahi" was the new religion started by
questions.solution: Solution:		The Din-i Ilahi (lit. "Religion of God") was a syncretic religion propounded by the Mughal emperor Akbar in 1582 CE, intending to merge some of the elements of the religions of his empire, and thereby reconcile the differences that divided his subjects.

questions.Question: Akbar held his religious discussion in
