questions.solution: Solution:		The Ibadat Khana (House of Worship) was a meeting house built in 1575 CE by the Mughal Emperor Akbar (r. 1556–1605) at Fatehpur Sikri to gather spiritual leaders of different religious grounds so as to conduct a discussion on the teachings of the respective religious leaders.

questions.Question: Who was the master of imperial mint at Delhi during the reign of Akbar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Khwaza Abdus Samad was the master of imperial mint at Delhi during the reign of Akbar.

questions.Question: The architectural raw material generally used in Akbar's period was
questions.solution: Solution:		The architectural raw material generally used in Akbar's period was Redstone.

questions.Question: Who was the trusted General of the Mughal emperor Akbar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Man Singh was the most trusted General of the Mughal emperor Akbar, he assisted him in many battles including the famous Battle of Haldighati (1576).

questions.Question: During Akbar's reign who was the Finance Minister of the Mughal empire?
questions.solution: Solution:		Raja Todarmal was the finance minister (Mushrif-i-Diwan) of Mughal Emperor Akbar, he was one of the navratnas of Akbar's court. He introduced land measurement system, Zabti/Dhasala system (revenue collection) and karori system.

questions.Question: Aurangzeb, in his attempt to annex Marwar to the Mughal empire, was involved in a 30-year war. During these long years the most valiant struggle from the side of Marwar was fought by
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurangzeb, in his attempt to annex Marwar to the Mughal empire, was involved in a 30-year war. During these long years the most valiant struggle from the side of Marwar was fought byDurgadas Rathore.

questions.Question:
I. Musamman Burj is situated inside the Fatehpur Sikri Fort
II. Aurangzeb built Moti Masjid inside Agra Fort
Which of the following option is correct related to the Mughal Architecture?
questions.optionA: Both I and II are correct
questions.optionB: Both I and II are incorrect
questions.solution: Solution:		Musamman Burj also known as the Saman Burj or the Shah-burj, is an octagonal tower standing close to the Shah Jahan's private hall Diwan-e-Khas in Agra Fort. The Moti Masjid (translation: Pearl Mosque) in Agra was built by Shah Jahan.

questions.Question: Aurangzeb appointed his uncle Shaista Khan as Governor of
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1660 Aurangzeb appointed Shaista Khan, his maternal uncle and a veteran general, viceroy of the Deccan, with instructions to suppress the activities of Shivaji.

questions.Question: Which of these is not one of the titles adopted by Aurangzeb?
questions.solution: Solution:		Suleiman I, commonly known as Suleiman the Magnificent in the West and Kanuni Sultan Suleyman in his realm, was the tenth and longest-reigning Sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1520 until his death in 1566.

questions.Question: Who amongst the following succeeded Aurangzeb?
questions.solution: Solution:		Abu'l Faaiz Qutb-ud-Din Muhammad Azam (28 June 1653 – 8 June 1707), commonly known as Azam Shah ("King Azam"), was a titular Mughal emperor, who reigned from 14 March 1707 to 8 June 1707. He was the eldest son of the sixth Mughal emperor Aurangzeb (also known as Alamgir) and his chief consort Dilras Banu Begum.

questions.Question: Bahadur Shah (First) was born in the year
questions.solution: Solution:		Bahadur Shah-I was the seventh Mughal Emperor. He was the third son of the Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb and Nawab Bai. He was born on Oct 14,1643.

questions.Question: Shah Jahan built the Moti Masjid at
questions.solution: Solution:		The Moti Masjid in Agra was built by Shah Jahan. During the rule of Shah Jahan the Mughal emperor, numerous architectural wonders were built, the most famous of them being the Taj Mahal. Moti Masjid earned the epithet Pearl Mosque for it shone like a pearl.

questions.Question: Shah Jahan was kept in prison by Aurangzeb at
questions.solution: Solution:		Shah Jahan recovered from his illness, but Aurangzeb put his father under house arrest in Agra Fort from July 1658 until his death in January 1666.

questions.Question: The Mughal ruler, Bahadur Shah II had been exiled by the British and sent to
questions.solution: Solution:		Bahadur Shah II's involvement in the Indian Rebellion of 1857, the British exiled him to Rangoon in British-controlled Burma (now in Myanmar), after convicting him on conspiracy charges.

questions.Question: Who called Muazzam as Shahi-i- Bekhabar?
questions.solution: Solution:		Kafi Khan called Muazzam as Shahi-i- Bekhabar.

questions.Question: Aurangzeb sent Mukarrab Khan against
questions.solution: Solution:		Mukarrab Khan with his large army attacked Sambhji Maharaj with an army of 4000. The 400 Maratha soldiers attacked so ferociously, that Mukarab Khan was taken by surprise. Sambhaji Maharaj along with Kavi Kalash was captured and taken as prisoner to Aurangzeb who killed him with utmost brutality.

questions.Question: Jizya was abolished by the Mughal ruler
questions.solution: Solution:		Jizya was abolished by the third Mughal emperor Akbar, in 1564. It was finally abolished in 1579.

questions.Question: Which of the following is not true about First Anglo-Mysore War?
questions.optionA: First Anglo-Mysore War fought in AD 1767-69
questions.optionB: Hyder Ali defeated the English in the First Anglo-Mysore War
questions.optionC: Treaty of Madras was the result of First Anglo-Mysore War
questions.optionD: All of the above are incorrect
questions.solution: Solution:		The First Anglo–Mysore War (1766–1769) was a conflict in India between the Sultanate of Mysore and the East India Company. The war was instigated in part by the machinations of Asaf Jah II, the Nizam of Hyderabad, who sought to divert the company's resources from attempts to gain control of the Northern Circars.

questions.Question: Under the Mughals __________ was administered as a department of the household
questions.solution: Solution:		Under the Mughals artillery was administered as a department of the household.

questions.Question: Which Mughal Emperor transferred the Mughal Capital from Agra to Delhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		The first Mughal emperor to crown Agra as capital of mughal empire, was Akbar in the year 1526. The capital of mughal empire was changed from Agra to Delhi by Shah Jahan in the year 1638.

questions.Question: Under the Mughal rule the Chief Minister was known as
questions.solution: Solution:Diwan: The Diwan was the finance minister responsible for a collection of revenue and remittance of it to the imperial treasury. The office was sometimes combined the that of Vizier. The Diwani (revenue office) was conferred on the East India Company by Shah Alam in 1765. This greatly enhanced the power of the British in India. In later years the term Diwan was also used for the prime minister of a princely state.Vakil: The Vakil was the royal deputy. It was a post filled only twice under the seven great Mughal emperors. Other ranks were in descending order:Kazi: The Chief Kazi was an Islamic scholar & judge and the expounder of canon law.Mansabdar: The Mansabdar (lit. rank holder) was the lowest grade of an official. They were divided into three functions: military, clerical and theological.

questions.Question: Name the king who invaded Delhi and plundered the Kohinoor diamond __________
questions.solution: Solution:		Nadir Shah of Iran invaded India in 1739 and took with him famous Mughal peacock throne and kohinoor diamond in the battle of Karnal.

questions.Question: During the Mughal period Polaj was the
questions.solution: Solution:		Polaj was the ideal and best type of land throughout the empire. This land was cultivated always and was never allowed to lie fallow.

questions.Question: What was the original name of Nur Jahan?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nur Jahan (born Mehr-un-Nissa) (31 May 1577 – 17 December 1645) was the twentieth (and last) wife of the Mughal emperor Jahangir.

questions.Question: The Mughals have been made immortal by their achievements in the field
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal architecture flourished in the Indian subcontinent from the 16th until the early 18th century when the Mughal Empire was at its height. The architectural style which is a unique blend of Islamic, Indian and Persian styles reached its golden age under Shah Jahan (ruled 1628-1658) who built the spectacular Taj Mahal and some other equally impressive monuments.

questions.Question: The Mughal empire reached its maximum territorial extent during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		Aurangzeb ruled 1658-1707 and expanded the empire to its greatest extent, shown by the heavy red line on the map.

questions.Question: Who of the following became a member of the "Din-i-Ilahi"?
questions.solution: Solution:		The theory of Din-i-Ilahi was introduced by Mughal Emperor Akbar. It is based on Monotheism(believe in one God).(Chief priest : Abul Fazal).The first initiated disciples of Din-i-ilahi during emperor Akbar the Great's time included Birbal, Prince Salim and Abul-Fazl ibn Mubarak.

questions.Question: Where is Muslim mosque situated where a hair of pagamber Mohammad Sahed has been preserved
questions.solution: Solution:		The Hazratbal Shrine (Urdu, Kashmiri:literally "Majestic Place"), is a Muslim shrine in Hazratbal, Srinagar, Jammu & Kashmir, India. It contains a relic, the Moi-e-Muqqadas, believed by many Muslims of Kashmir to be a hair of the Islamic prophet Muhammad.

questions.Question: Under the Mughals the Commander-in-Chief of the Army was
questions.solution: Solution:		Commander-in-Chief, Mughal emperor. The Army of the Mughal Empire was the force by which the Mughal emperors established their empire in the 15th century and expanded it to its greatest extent at the beginning of the 18th century.

questions.Question: The Persian ruler who besieged Qandhar in Jahangir's reign was
questions.solution: Solution:		The Persian ruler who besieged Qandhar in Jahangir's reign was Shah Abbas.

questions.Question: Who constructed Humayun's tomb in Delhi?
questions.solution: Solution:		The tomb of Humayun was built by the orders of Humayun's first wife and chief consort, Empress Bega Begum (also known as Haji Begum). The construction began in 1565, nine years after his death, and completed in 1572 AD at a cost of 1.5 million ruppees at the time.

questions.Question: Humayun had to run away from India after he was defeated in the battle of
questions.solution: Solution:		Humayun was defeated in the battle of kannauj by Shershah Suri (1540). After this battle Sher Shah Suri forced him out of India.

questions.Question: Whom did Akbar defeat in the 2nd battle of Panipat in 1556?
questions.solution: Solution:		The Second Battle of Panipat was fought on November 5, 1556, between the forces of Hem Chandra Vikramaditya, the king at Delhi and forces of Emperor Akbar.

questions.Question: Akbar suppressed the rebellion of Abdullah Khan, the Governor of
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar appointed Abdullah Khan as the governor of Malwa with his headquarters at Mandu. Akbar suppressed the rebellion of Abdullah Khan, the Governor of Malwa.

questions.Question: Akbar married a bride from
questions.solution: Solution:		Akbar married a bride from Udaipur.

questions.Question: Who among the following was the first to make use of artillery in warfare in medieval India?
questions.solution: Solution:		Babur was the first to make use of artillery and gunpowder fire arms in warfare during the first Battle of Panipat in 1526.

questions.Question: During the Mughal rule in India tobacco was first cultivated in
questions.solution: Solution:		Tobacco manufacture can scarcely have started in India during Akbar's reign. Firstly in the province of Gujarat, where the leaf was obtainable in the 1613.

questions.Question: The second Battle of Panipat was fought between
questions.solution: Solution:		The Second Battle of Panipat was fought between the forces of Samrat Hem Chandra Vikramaditya, popularly called Hemu, the Hindu king who was ruling North India from Delhi, and the army of Akbar, on November 5, 1556. It was a decisive victory for Akbar's generals Khan Zaman I and Bairam Khan.

questions.Question: The most important feature of the Mughal building was the
questions.solution: Solution:		The most important features of the Mughal monuments in India are the bulbous domes with constricted necks, the slender minarets with cupolas at the four corners, large halls, massive vaulted gateways and delicate ornamentation. Red Sandstone was amply used in Mughal monuments.

questions.Question: During Mughal rule, excellent cotton goods were woven in which one of the following centres?
questions.solution: Solution:		During Mughal rule, excellent cotton goods were woven in Agra. The manufacture of cotton cloth was the principal industry.

questions.Question: When Chittor was captured by Akbar (1558), the Rana of Mewar was
questions.solution: Solution:		When Chittor was captured by Akbar (1558), the Rana of Mewar was Rana Udai Singh.

questions.Question: When Babur invaded India in 1525, Humayun was the Governor of
questions.solution: Solution:		Babar set out on his final invasion of India in November, 1525. His eldest son, Humayun, brought a contingent from Badakhshan, and Khwaja Kalan, trustiest of generals, led the troops of Ghazni.

questions.Question: Baburnama was written by
questions.solution: Solution:		The "Memoirs of Babur" or Baburnama are the work of the great-great-great-grandson of Timur (Tamerlane), Zahiruddin Muhammad Babur (1483-1530).

questions.Question: Humayun (1530-1540 AD) was the ruler of which dynasty?
questions.solution: Solution:		Nasir-ud-Din Muḥammad, better known by his regional name, Humayun, was the second emperor of the Mughal Empire, who ruled over territory in what is now Afghanistan, Pakistan, Northern India and Bangladesh from 1530–1540 and again from 1555–1556.

questions.Question: Defeated Humayun in the Battle of Kannauj (1540) also constructed the Purana Qila of New Delhi
questions.solution: Solution:		On 26 June 1539, Sher Khan faced Humayun in the Battle of Chausa and defeated him. Assuming the title Farid al-Din Sher Shah, he defeated Humayun once again at Kannauj in May 1540 and forced him out of India. He also constructed the Purana Qila of New Delhi.

questions.Question: The Mughal subdued the Pathans by following the policy of
questions.solution: Solution:		By 1675 A.D. Mughal authority was reestablished in the north-western frontier. The Pathan tribes were finally subdued by the policy of divide and rule.

questions.Question: Who was the Mughal Prince who was well-versed in Arabic, Persian and Sanakrit?
questions.solution: Solution:		Prince Dara Shukoh was the Mughal Prince who was well-versed in Arabic, Persian and Sanskrit.

questions.Question: In 1739, who defeated the Mughal army at the Battle of Karnal?
questions.solution: Solution:		Emperor Nader Shah, the Shah of Persia (1736–47) and the founder of the Afsharid dynasty of Persia, invaded the Mughal Empire, eventually attacking Delhi in March 1739. His army had easily defeated the Mughals at the battle at Karnal and would eventually capture the Mughal capital in the aftermath of the battle.

questions.Question: Who introduced the Subsidiary Alliance System in India?
questions.solution: Solution:		The doctrine of subsidiary alliance was introduced by Lord Wellesley, British Governor-General in India from 1798 to 1805. Early in his governorship Wellesley adopted a policy of non-intervention in the princely states, but he later adopted the policy of forming subsidiary alliances.

questions.Question: Vasco da Gama a sailor belongs to __________.
questions.solution: Solution:		Vasco da Gama (1469 or 1469-December 24, 1524) was a Portuguese sailor. He was the first European who went to India through the Cape of Good Hope, the southern end of Africa in Cape Town. He went to India three times by ship. He was born in Sines, Portugal.

questions.Question: Mughal presence in the Red fort was ceased by
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal presence in the Red fort was ceased by East India Company under Commander John Nicholsan with the fall of Bahadur Shah Zafar during the Revolt of 1857.

questions.Question: The Mughal Emperor who discouraged 'Sati' was
questions.solution: Solution:		Sati were supposed to be voluntary. Since it was offensive to the sentiments of the Mughals, its rulers such as Akbar the Great explicitly banned involuntary sati. On a superficial level, therefore, most these women were not resistant to committing sati at all.

questions.Question: Which of the following Mughal Emperors wrote their own autobigraphies?
questions.solution: Solution:		Mughal Emperor Babur wrote his autobiography Baburnama. (Tuzk-e-Babri) in Chapatai Language and Mughal Emperor Jahangir wrote autobiography Tuzuk-e-Jahangiri which is written in Persian Language.

questions.Question: The huge wealth of the Mughals Cell into the hands of __________ after the capture of Delhi in 1739
questions.solution: Solution:		Emperor Nader Shah, the Shah of Persia (1736–47) and the founder of the Afsharid dynasty of Persia, invaded the Mughal Empire, eventually attacking Delhi in March 1739. His army had easily defeated the Mughals at the battle at Karnal and would eventually capture the Mughal capital in the aftermath of the battle.

questions.Question: The court language of the Mughals was
questions.solution: Solution:		Humayun's exile in Persia established diplomatic ties between the Safavid and Mughal Courts, and led to increasing Persian cultural influence in the Mughal Empire.

questions.Question: What was the policy of "doctrine of lapse"?
questions.optionA: States were allowed to adopt son as an heir
questions.optionB: States were not allowed to adopt son as an heir
questions.optionC: According to this system, every ruler in India had to accept to pay a subsidy to the British for the maintenance of British army
questions.solution: Solution:		This doctrine was based on the idea that in case a ruler of dependent state died childless, the right of ruling over the State reverted or 'lapsed' to the sovereign.

questions.Question: Which of the following are the four Agnikula classes of Rajputs?
questions.solution: Solution:		Clans that are included in the agnikula rajputs are Pariharas, Chauhans, Pawars, Solankis.

questions.Question: During the Mughal rule in the field of agriculture Parauti was the land
questions.solution: Solution:		Parauti was the land which had to be left fallow for one or two years to recoup the fertility.

questions.Question: Two Sayid brothers Sayid Abdullah Khan and Sayid Hussan Ali Khan (who rose to become the king makers during the later Mughal period) met their downfall during the reign of
questions.solution: Solution:		Two Sayyid brothers Sayyid Abdullah Khan and Shahid Hassan Ali Khan (who rose to become the king makers during the later Mughal period) met their downfall during the reign of Muhammad Shah.

questions.Question:
I. Hawkins was the first Englishman to visit Jahangir's court
II. Hawkins was called by the name of English Khan, by Jahangir
Which of the above statement (s) is/are correct related to Hawkins?
questions.optionA: Both I and II are correct
questions.optionB: Both I and II are incorrect
questions.solution: Solution:		Hawkins was the first Englishman to visit Jahangir's court. Hawkins was called by the name of English Khan, by Jahangir. This English Khan was able to persuade the emperor to grant a commission for an English factory at Surat but under the Pressure of the Portuguese Viceroy, the grant was withdrawn.

questions.Question: Arab merchant, Suleiman, came to India in 9th century in the kingdom of
questions.solution: Solution:		Arab merchant, Suleiman, came to India in 9th century in the kingdom was Mihira Bhoja of Prathihara dynasty.

questions.Question: The famous Peacock Throne of Shah Jahan was taken away in 1739 by
questions.solution: Solution:		In 1739, Persian invader Nadir Shah plundered and looted Delhi,and the Peacock throne was taken away along with other spoils. It was believed that after Nadir Shah’s death the Peacock throne was broken down and damaged.

questions.Question: Which of these is not correctly matched regarding the reign of Shahjahan?
questions.solution: Solution:		Sunder Das was a poet.

questions.Question:
Consider the following statement (s) related to the Zeb-un-nisa
I. Zeb-un-nisa chose to live voluntarily with Shah Jahan and later was awarded great honour by Aurangzeb.
II. Zeb-un-nisa was the sister of Shah Jahan.
questions.optionA: Both I and II are correct
questions.optionB: Both I and II are incorrect
questions.solution: Solution:		Zeb-un-nisa was a Mughal princess, the eldest child of Emperor Aurangzeb and his chief consort Dilras Banu Begum. Zeb-un-nisa chose to live voluntarily with Shah Jahan and later was awarded great honour by Aurangzeb.

questions.Question: Bahadur Shah was the
questions.optionD: Successor of the Maratha ruler Shivaji
questions.solution: Solution:		Mirza Abu Zafar Siraj-ud-din Muhammad Bahadur Shah Zafar was the last Mughal emperor. He was the second son of and became the successor to his father, Akbar II, upon his death on 28 September 1837.
